Is my understanding correct? "The notes will not be redeemable prior to October 5, 2027. The notes will be redeemable, in whole or in part (subject to certain limitations on partial redemptions), for cash at the option of Pagaya US at any time, and from time to time, on or after October 5, 2027 and on or before the 41st scheduled trading day immediately before the maturity date, but only if the last reported sale price per Class A ordinary share of Pagaya exceeds 130% of the exchange price for a specified period of time and certain other conditions are satisfied."

The offering notes were over subscribed, thus offering is increased!
Then the redemption price will be $13.9 and cannot be redeemable until 2027!

Hard to believe the market misunderstands the note issuance to this large an extent.  This stock has traded over 25% of its share float and the day hasn't ended.  This is essentially just a routine note issue with an extremely unlikely possibility of a per share accounting dilution 5 years from now with no shares added to the float no matter what.  It just gives the company an automatic "escape route" in the event it doesn't happen to have free cash to repay the notes when they come due which is a benefit for the company.  As it continues to issue larger and larger ABS deals and it has to keep some participation (although it has managed to lower its percentage), it is required to keep certain reserves on hand.  This is just part of the ordinary increase in those required reserves.  It even provides an automatic resolution if it doesn't happen to have sufficient free cash on the due date so there is no possiblity of any default.

Shares at these prices are an absolute steal for one of the largest if not the largest company providing AI software to boost the amount of loans approved for customers of various businesses along with a remarkable track record of lowering loss ratios on those loans.  That allows it to be able to package those loans into ABS and issue them while it collects fees on both ends of the financing.  With great demand, it has reduced its own money in each deal which lowers the risk to PGY and provides a third source of income. Today's reaction is overdone by those who fail to understand that the new notes are essentially designed to prevent any dilution.  It is likely no shares will ever be issued.  The company controls whether it pays the debt in shares and those shares are not eligible to be listed for trading in the public market.  Private purchasers of this debt must have full confidence in getting paid back.  Otherwise, they would not invest but they are prepared to accept payment in non-tradeable shares if the company chooses to pay them off that way.  If it does not have the cash or ability to place more debt at that time, it insures there is no possibility of an actual default.  If shares were issued, the company would have a plan to redeem them at some point as the holders have no practical way to sell them except to another private buyer.  Ultimately, there is no dilution to the float of its shares.  Any "dilution" for accounting purposes would be temporary and minimal.

Investors have ignored the clear statement on the debt offering and the trading in the thin off hours is mistaken.  There is no dilution and will be no dilution to the float on the market:  "The offer and sale of the notes, the guarantee and any Class A ordinary shares of Pagaya deliverable upon exchange of the notes HAVE NOT BEEN, AND WILL NOT BE,  registered under the Securities Act or any other securities laws, and the notes and any such shares cannot be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any other applicable securities laws."  (emphasis added by me).  Obviously, it is clear that the notes are intended to be paid off in cash but just in case, there is a provision to allow payment in unregistered shares that cannot be sold in the public market but would either have to be sold to other qualifed private buyers or the company would end up buying them back at some delayed date.  The shares could never be dumped on the market.

"KBW published their post earnings report. PT of $23/share and "outperform" rating. I felt the quarter was good and had a single negative. KBW highlights the same. Felt the quarter was "solid" and if they had to "pick" one thing it was the impairment. KBW highlights that mngt believes this isn't ongoing and proof of that is their guidance that 2025 will be GAAP net income positive. If they were to have more large impairments you can't be GAAP net income positive. On-going impairments would make that impossible. Many have asked why the sell off post earnings. Here is KBW's thoughts. "Why Such a Sharp Sell-off in PGY? We did not get a lot of investor feedback one way or the other on the stock and quarter, which suggests to us this was mainly profit- taking, with the stock having been up 18% since mid-June." KBW Bottom-Line With the stock having round-tripped since June (after being up over 18%), we think the entry point presently is attractive for the shares. In the two months since we initiated coverage, PGY has only furthered its model in terms of its partnerships on both sides of its model, achieved AAA rating on securitizations (helping capital efficacy) and accomplished the key goal of self-funding its growth. Additionally, with interest rates on the cusp of decline, that should add to the attractiveness of PGY‚Äôs loan sales. Reiterate OP rating."
